name: Trace
comment: A stack trace, comprised of a list of stack frames.

frames.name: frames
frames.comment: The stack frames that comprise this stack trace.

vmTrace.name: vmTrace
vmTrace.comment:
Returns a VM-style dart-core.StackTrace object.

The return value's stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.toString method will always return a string representation in the Dart VM's stack trace format, regardless of what platform is being used.

terse.name: terse
terse.comment:
Returns a terser version of this.

This is accomplished by folding together multiple stack frames from the core library or from this package, as in stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.foldFrames. Remaining core library frames have their libraries, "-patch" suffixes, and line numbers removed.

current.name: current
current.comment:
Returns the current stack trace.

By default, the first frame of this trace will be the line where stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.Trace-current is called. If stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.Trace-current.level is passed, the trace will start that many frames up instead.

from.name: from
from.comment:
Returns a new stack trace containing the same data as stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.Trace-from.trace.

If stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.Trace-from.trace is a native dart-core.StackTrace, its data will be parsed out; if it's a stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace, it will be returned as-is.

parse.name: parse
parse.comment:
Parses a string representation of a stack trace.

stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.Trace-parse.trace should be formatted in the same way as a Dart VM or browser stack trace.

parseVM.name: parseVM
parseVM.comment: Parses a string representation of a Dart VM stack trace.

parseV8.name: parseV8
parseV8.comment: Parses a string representation of a Chrome/V8 stack trace.

parseIE.name: parseIE
parseIE.comment:
Parses a string representation of an Internet Explorer stack trace.

IE10+ traces look just like V8 traces. Prior to IE10, stack traces can't be retrieved.

parseFirefox.name: parseFirefox
parseFirefox.comment: Parses a string representation of a Firefox stack trace.

parseSafari.name: parseSafari
parseSafari.comment:
Parses a string representation of a Safari stack trace.

This will automatically decide between parseSafari6_0 and parseSafari6_1 based on the contents of stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.Trace-parseSafari.trace.

parseSafari6_1.name: parseSafari6_1
parseSafari6_1.comment: Parses a string representation of a Safari 6.1+ stack trace.

parseSafari6_0.name: parseSafari6_0
parseSafari6_0.comment:
Parses a string representation of a Safari 6.0 stack trace.

Safari 6.0 stack traces look just like Firefox traces, except that they sometimes (e.g. in isolates) have a "native code" frame. We just ignore this frame to make the stack format more consistent between browsers. Prior to Safari 6.0, stack traces can't be retrieved.

parseFriendly.name: parseFriendly
parseFriendly.comment:
Parses this package's string representation of a stack trace.

This also parses string representations of stack_trace/stack_trace.Chains. They parse to the same trace that stack_trace/stack_trace-chain.Chain.toTrace would return.

format.name: format
format.comment: Returns a human-readable representation of stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.format.stackTrace. If stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.format.terse is set, this folds together multiple stack frames from the Dart core libraries, so that only the core library method directly called from user code is visible (see stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.terse).

foldFrames.name: foldFrames
foldFrames.comment:
Returns a new stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace based on this where multiple stack frames matching stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.foldFrames.predicate are folded together. This means that whenever there are multiple frames in a row that match stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.foldFrames.predicate, only the last one is kept.

This is useful for limiting the amount of library code that appears in a stack trace by only showing user code and code that's called by user code.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a human-readable string representation of this.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment:
Returns a dart-core.String representation of the stack trace.

The string represents the full stack trace starting from the point where a throw ocurred to the top of the current call sequence.

The exact format of the string representation is not final.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.
